    • Method Detail

      • getInt

        public static int getInt​(int[] accepts,
                         java.lang.String inputPrompt,
                         java.lang.String errorPrompt)
        Fetches int from user. Also fixes the getInt();getNextLine(); problem for you. You can use an inline declaration of int[] accepts like this: getInt(new int[]{1, 2, 3}, null, null) Also avoids the getInt();getNextLine(); problem for you.
        Parameters:
        accepts - - int[] specifying accepted inputs
        inputPrompt - - Can be null to use default prompt
        errorPrompt - - Can be null to use default error message when input is invalid
        Returns:
        int - User input cast to int

      • getInt

        public static int getInt()
        Shorthand no-arg overload for getInt(int[], String, String)
        Returns:
        int

      • getIntFromRange

        public static int getIntFromRange​(int lowerLimit,
                                  int upperLimit,
                                  java.lang.String inPrompt,
                                  java.lang.String errPrompt)
        Fetches int within a specific range from user. The accepted values are inclusive of the lower and upper limit, so the accepted values for getIntFromRange(0, 3) are [0, 3]. Also avoids the getInt();getNextLine(); problem for you.
        Parameters:
        lowerLimit - - Lower bound of accepted value, inclusive
        upperLimit - - Upper bound of accepted value, inclusive
        inPrompt - - Can be null to use default prompt
        errPrompt - - Can be null to use default error message when input is invalid
        Returns:
        int - User input cast to int

      • getIntFromRange

        public static int getIntFromRange​(int lowerLimit,
                                  int upperLimit)
        Shorthand overload for getIntFromRange(int, int, String, String)
        Returns:
        int

      • getDouble

        public static double getDouble​(java.lang.Double min,
                               java.lang.Double max,
                               java.lang.String inputPrompt,
                               java.lang.String errorPrompt)
        Fetches double within a specific range from user. The accepted values are inclusive of the lower and upper limit, so the accepted values for getDouble(0, 3) are [0.0, 3.0]. Also fixes the getDouble();getNextLine(); problem for you.
        Parameters:
        min - - Lower bound of accepted ints, inclusive
        max - - Upper bound of accepted ints, inclusive
        inputPrompt - - Can be null to use default prompt
        errorPrompt - - Can be null to use default error message when input is invalid
        Returns:
        double - user input cast to double

      • getDouble

        public static double getDouble()
        Shorthand no-arg overload for getDouble(Double, Double, String, String)
        Returns:
        double

      • getString

        public static java.lang.String getString​(java.lang.Integer maxLen,
                                         java.lang.String inputFormat,
                                         java.lang.String errorFormat)
        Fetches string from user with the specified maximum character length.
        Parameters:
        maxLen - - int indicating maximum length of input. Defaults to Integer.MAX_VALUE.
        inputFormat - - Can be null to use default prompt
        errorFormat - - Can be null to use default error message when input is invalid
        Returns:
        String

        Returns:
        String

      • getDate

        public static java.util.Date getDate​(java.lang.String inputPrompt,
                                     java.lang.String errorPrompt)
        Fetches Date input from user in a specific format. Checking for valid date formats happens inside stringToDate(String)
        Parameters:
        inputPrompt - - Can be null to use default prompt
        errorPrompt - - Can be null to use default error message when input is invalid
        Returns:
        Date

      • getDate

        public static java.util.Date getDate()
        Shorthand no-arg overload for getDate(String, String)
        Returns:
        Date

      • getPhoneNumber

        public static int getPhoneNumber​(java.lang.String inputPrompt,
                                 java.lang.String errorPrompt)
        Fetches phone number from user in a specific format. Note that 0 is a possible return value if the user inputs "0". This is useful as a sentinel value for "canceling". Checking for valid phone number formats happens inside phoneNumberStringToInt(String)
        Parameters:
        inputPrompt - - Can be null to use default prompt
        errorPrompt - - Can be null to use default error message when input is invalid
        Returns:
        int

      • getPhoneNumber

        public static int getPhoneNumber()
        Shorthand no-arg overload for getString(Integer, String, String)
        Returns:
        String

      • stringToDate

        public static java.util.Date stringToDate​(java.lang.String s)
        Converts input String to Date object. Can return null if input string does not match Date format. So far supported inputs are:
      • today
      • tomorrow
      • tmr
      • DD/MM
        • format, like 22/03 for 22 Mar 2019 (resolves to date in current year)
      • DD/MM/YYYY
        • format, like 22/03/2018 the year must start with 1 or 2)
Parameters:
s - - Input string to parse to Date
Returns:
Date or null if input is not in recognised format.

  • phoneNumberStringToInt

    public static java.lang.Integer phoneNumberStringToInt​(java.lang.String s)
    Converts input String to phone number as an int object. Phone numbers must start with 6, 8 or 9 and have 8 digits in total. There can be any number of spaces or hyphens (-) in the input string. Can return 0 if input string is "0". Can return null if input string does not match phone number format.
    Parameters:
    s - - Input string to parse to phone number
    Returns:
    int or null if input is not in recognised format.
